member.name: T:OpenTK.Audio.ALListenerf
member.summary: A list of valid 32-Bits Float Listener/GetListener parameters

member.name: F:OpenTK.Audio.ALListenerf.Gain
member.summary: Indicate the gain (Volume amplification) applied. Type: float Range: [0.0f - ? ] A value of 1.0 means un-attenuated/unchanged. Each division by 2 equals an attenuation of -6dB. Each multiplicaton with 2 equals an amplification of +6dB. A value of 0.0f is interpreted as zero volume and the channel is effectively disabled.

member.name: F:OpenTK.Audio.ALListenerf.EfxMetersPerUnit
member.summary: (EFX Extension) This setting is critical if Air Absorption effects are enabled because the amount of Air Absorption applied is directly related to the real-world distance between the Source and the Listener. centimeters 0.01f meters 1.0f kilometers 1000.0f Range [float.MinValue .. float.MaxValue] Default: 1.0f

member.name: T:OpenTK.Audio.ALListener3f
member.summary: A list of valid Math.Vector3 Listener/GetListener parameters

member.name: F:OpenTK.Audio.ALListener3f.Position
member.summary: Specify the current location in three dimensional space. OpenAL, like OpenGL, uses a right handed coordinate system, where in a frontal default view X (thumb) points right, Y points up (index finger), and Z points towards the viewer/camera (middle finger). To switch from a left handed coordinate system, flip the sign on the Z coordinate. Listener position is always in the world coordinate system.

member.name: F:OpenTK.Audio.ALListener3f.Velocity
member.summary: Specify the current velocity in three dimensional space.

member.name: T:OpenTK.Audio.ALListenerfv
member.summary: A list of valid float[] Listener/GetListener parameters

member.name: F:OpenTK.Audio.ALListenerfv.Orientation
member.summary: Indicate Listener orientation. Expects two Vector3, At followed by Up.

member.name: T:OpenTK.Audio.ALSourcef
member.summary: A list of valid 32-Bits Float Source/GetSource parameters

member.name: F:OpenTK.Audio.ALSourcef.ReferenceDistance
member.summary: Source specific reference distance. Type: float Range: [0.0f - float.PositiveInfinity] At 0.0f, no distance attenuation occurs. Type: float Default: 1.0f.

member.name: F:OpenTK.Audio.ALSourcef.MaxDistance
member.summary: Indicate distance above which Sources are not attenuated using the inverse clamped distance model. Default: float.PositiveInfinity Type: float Range: [0.0f - float.PositiveInfinity]

member.name: F:OpenTK.Audio.ALSourcef.RolloffFactor
member.summary: Source specific rolloff factor. Type: float Range: [0.0f - float.PositiveInfinity]

member.name: F:OpenTK.Audio.ALSourcef.Pitch
member.summary: Specify the pitch to be applied, either at Source, or on mixer results, at Listener. Range: [0.5f - 2.0f] Default: 1.0f

member.name: F:OpenTK.Audio.ALSourcef.Gain
member.summary: Indicate the gain (volume amplification) applied. Type: float. Range: [0.0f - ? ] A value of 1.0 means un-attenuated/unchanged. Each division by 2 equals an attenuation of -6dB. Each multiplicaton with 2 equals an amplification of +6dB. A value of 0.0f is meaningless with respect to a logarithmic scale; it is interpreted as zero volume - the channel is effectively disabled.

member.name: F:OpenTK.Audio.ALSourcef.MinGain
member.summary: Indicate minimum Source attenuation. Type: float Range: [0.0f - 1.0f] (Logarthmic)

member.name: F:OpenTK.Audio.ALSourcef.MaxGain
member.summary: Indicate maximum Source attenuation. Type: float Range: [0.0f - 1.0f] (Logarthmic)

member.name: F:OpenTK.Audio.ALSourcef.ConeInnerAngle
member.summary: Directional Source, inner cone angle, in degrees. Range: [0-360] Default: 360

member.name: F:OpenTK.Audio.ALSourcef.ConeOuterAngle
member.summary: Directional Source, outer cone angle, in degrees. Range: [0-360] Default: 360

member.name: F:OpenTK.Audio.ALSourcef.ConeOuterGain
member.summary: Directional Source, outer cone gain. Default: 0.0f Range: [0.0f - 1.0] (Logarithmic)

member.name: F:OpenTK.Audio.ALSourcef.SecOffset
member.summary: The playback position, expressed in seconds.

member.name: F:OpenTK.Audio.ALSourcef.EfxAirAbsorptionFactor
member.summary: (EFX Extension) This property is a multiplier on the amount of Air Absorption applied to the Source. The AL_AIR_ABSORPTION_FACTOR is multiplied by an internal Air Absorption Gain HF value of 0.994 (-0.05dB) per meter which represents normal atmospheric humidity and temperature. Range [0.0f .. 10.0f] Default: 0.0f

member.name: F:OpenTK.Audio.ALSourcef.EfxRoomRolloffFactor
member.summary: (EFX Extension) This property is defined the same way as the Reverb Room Rolloff property: it is one of two methods available in the Effect Extension to attenuate the reflected sound (early reflections and reverberation) according to source-listener distance. Range [0.0f .. 10.0f] Default: 0.0f

member.name: F:OpenTK.Audio.ALSourcef.EfxConeOuterGainHighFrequency
member.summary: (EFX Extension) A directed Source points in a specified direction. The Source sounds at full volume when the listener is directly in front of the source; it is attenuated as the listener circles the Source away from the front. Range [0.0f .. 1.0f] Default: 1.0f

member.name: T:OpenTK.Audio.ALSource3f
member.summary: A list of valid Math.Vector3 Source/GetSource parameters

member.name: F:OpenTK.Audio.ALSource3f.Position
member.summary: Specify the current location in three dimensional space. OpenAL, like OpenGL, uses a right handed coordinate system, where in a frontal default view X (thumb) points right, Y points up (index finger), and Z points towards the viewer/camera (middle finger). To switch from a left handed coordinate system, flip the sign on the Z coordinate. Listener position is always in the world coordinate system.

member.name: F:OpenTK.Audio.ALSource3f.Velocity
member.summary: Specify the current velocity in three dimensional space.

member.name: F:OpenTK.Audio.ALSource3f.Direction
member.summary: Specify the current direction vector.

member.name: T:OpenTK.Audio.ALSourceb
member.summary: A list of valid 8-Bits boolean Source/GetSource parameters

member.name: F:OpenTK.Audio.ALSourceb.SourceRelative
member.summary: Indicate that the Source has relative coordinates. Type: bool Range: [True, False]

member.name: F:OpenTK.Audio.ALSourceb.Looping
member.summary: Indicate whether the Source is looping. Type: bool Range: [True, False] Default: False.

member.name: F:OpenTK.Audio.ALSourceb.EfxDirectFilterGainHighFrequencyAuto
member.summary: (EFX Extension) If this Source property is set to True, this Sources direct-path is automatically filtered according to the orientation of the source relative to the listener and the setting of the Source property Sourcef.ConeOuterGainHF. Type: bool Range [False, True] Default: True

member.name: F:OpenTK.Audio.ALSourceb.EfxAuxiliarySendFilterGainAuto
member.summary: (EFX Extension) If this Source property is set to True, the intensity of this Sources reflected sound is automatically attenuated according to source-listener distance and source directivity (as determined by the cone parameters). If it is False, the reflected sound is not attenuated according to distance and directivity. Type: bool Range [False, True] Default: True

member.name: F:OpenTK.Audio.ALSourceb.EfxAuxiliarySendFilterGainHighFrequencyAuto
member.summary: (EFX Extension) If this Source property is AL_TRUE (its default value), the intensity of this Sources reflected sound at high frequencies will be automatically attenuated according to the high-frequency source directivity as set by the Sourcef.ConeOuterGainHF property. If this property is AL_FALSE, the Sources reflected sound is not filtered at all according to the Sources directivity. Type: bool Range [False, True] Default: True

member.name: F:OpenTK.Audio.ALSource3i.EfxAuxiliarySendFilter
member.summary: (EFX Extension) This Source property is used to establish connections between Sources and Auxiliary Effect Slots. For a Source to feed an Effect that has been loaded into an Auxiliary Effect Slot the application must configure one of the Sources auxiliary sends. This process involves setting 3 variables the destination Auxiliary Effect Slot ID, the Auxiliary Send number, and an optional Filter ID. Type: uint Range: any valid Filter Handle.

member.summary: Constructs a new AudioContext, using the default audio device.

member.summary: Constructs a new AudioContext, using the specified audio device.

member.remarks: Use AudioContext.AvailableDevices to obtain a list of all available audio devices. devices.

member.name: M:OpenTK.Audio.AudioContext.#ctor(System.String,System.Int32)
member.summary: Constructs a new AudioContext, using the specified audio device and device parameters.
member.param: The name of the audio device to use.
Frequency for mixing output buffer, in units of Hz. Pass 0 for driver default.
member.remarks: Use AudioContext.AvailableDevices to obtain a list of all available audio devices. devices.

member.summary: Constructs a new AudioContext, using the specified audio device and device parameters.
member.param: The name of the audio device to use.
Frequency for mixing output buffer, in units of Hz. Pass 0 for driver default.
Refresh intervals, in units of Hz. Pass 0 for driver default.
member.remarks: Use AudioContext.AvailableDevices to obtain a list of all available audio devices. devices.

member.name: M:OpenTK.Audio.AudioContext.#ctor(System.String,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Constructs a new AudioContext, using the specified audio device and device parameters.
member.param: The name of the audio device to use.
Frequency for mixing output buffer, in units of Hz. Pass 0 for driver default.
Refresh intervals, in units of Hz. Pass 0 for driver default.
Flag, indicating a synchronous context.
member.remarks: Use AudioContext.AvailableDevices to obtain a list of all available audio devices. devices.

member.name: M:OpenTK.Audio.AudioContext.#ctor(System.String,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Creates the audio context using the specified device and device parameters.
member.param: The device descriptor obtained through AudioContext.AvailableDevices.
Frequency for mixing output buffer, in units of Hz. Pass 0 for driver default.
Refresh intervals, in units of Hz. Pass 0 for driver default.
Flag, indicating a synchronous context.
Indicates whether the EFX extension should be initialized, if present.
member.exception: Occurs when the device string is invalid.
Occurs when a specified parameter is invalid.
Occurs when the specified device is not available, or is in use by another program.
Occurs when an audio context could not be created with the specified parameters.
Occurs when an AudioContext already exists.

remarks.para: For maximum compatibility, you are strongly recommended to use the default constructor.
Multiple AudioContexts are not supported at this point.

The number of auxilliary EFX sends depends on the audio hardware and drivers. Most Realtek devices, as well as the Creative SB Live!, support 1 auxilliary send. Creative's Audigy and X-Fi series support 4 sends. Values higher than supported will be clamped by the driver.

member.name: M:OpenTK.Audio.AudioContext.LoadAvailableDevices
member.summary: Loads all available audio devices into the available_devices array.
member.remarks: Only called by the static AudioContext constructor.

members.member:
Creates the audio context using the specified device. The device descriptor obtained through AudioContext.AvailableDevices, or null for the default device. Frequency for mixing output buffer, in units of Hz. Pass 0 for driver default. Refresh intervals, in units of Hz. Pass 0 for driver default. Flag, indicating a synchronous context. Indicates whether the EFX extension should be initialized, if present. /// Occurs when a specified parameter is invalid.
Occurs when the specified device is not available, or is in use by another program.
Occurs when an audio context could not be created with the specified parameters.
Occurs when an AudioContext already exists.
For maximum compatibility, you are strongly recommended to use the default constructor.
Multiple AudioContexts are not supported at this point.
The number of auxilliary EFX sends depends on the audio hardware and drivers. Most Realtek devices, as well as the Creative SB Live!, support 1 auxilliary send. Creative's Audigy and X-Fi series support 4 sends. Values higher than supported will be clamped by the driver.

member.name: M:OpenTK.Audio.AudioContext.MakeCurrent(OpenTK.Audio.AudioContext)
member.summary: Makes the specified AudioContext current in the calling thread.
member.param: The OpenTK.Audio.AudioContext to make current, or null.
member.exception: Occurs if this function is called after the AudioContext has been disposed.
Occurs when the AudioContext could not be made current.

member.name: M:OpenTK.Audio.AudioContext.MakeCurrent
member.summary: Makes the AudioContext current in the calling thread.
member.exception: Occurs if this function is called after the AudioContext has been disposed.
Occurs when the AudioContext could not be made current.
member.remarks: Only one AudioContext can be current in the application at any time, regardless of the number of threads.

member.name: M:OpenTK.Audio.AudioContext.Process
member.summary: Processes queued audio events.

remarks.para: If AudioContext.IsSynchronized is true, this function will resume the internal audio processing thread. If AudioContext.IsSynchronized is false, you will need to call this function multiple times per second to process audio events.
In some implementations this function may have no effect.

member.exception: Occurs when this function is called after the AudioContext had been disposed.

member.name: M:OpenTK.Audio.AudioContext.Suspend
member.summary: Suspends processing of audio events.

remarks.para: To avoid audio artifacts when calling this function, set audio gain to zero before suspending an AudioContext.
In some implementations, it can be faster to suspend processing before changing AudioContext state.
In some implementations this function may have no effect.

member.exception: Occurs when this function is called after the AudioContext had been disposed.

member.name: M:OpenTK.Audio.AudioContext.SupportsExtension(System.String)
member.summary: Checks whether the specified OpenAL extension is supported.
member.param: The name of the extension to check (e.g. "ALC_EXT_EFX").
member.returns: true if the extension is supported; false otherwise.

member.name: M:OpenTK.Audio.AudioContext.Dispose
member.summary: Disposes of the AudioContext, cleaning up all resources consumed by it.

member.name: P:OpenTK.Audio.AudioContext.IsCurrent
member.summary: Gets or sets a System.Boolean indicating whether the AudioContext is current.
member.remarks: Only one AudioContext can be current in the application at any time, regardless of the number of threads.

member.name: P:OpenTK.Audio.AudioContext.IsProcessing
member.summary: Gets a System.Boolean indicating whether the AudioContext is currently processing audio events.

member.name: P:OpenTK.Audio.AudioContext.IsSynchronized
member.summary: Gets a System.Boolean indicating whether the AudioContext is synchronized.

member.name: P:OpenTK.Audio.AudioContext.CurrentContext
member.summary: Gets the OpenTK.Audio.AudioContext which is current in the application.
member.remarks: Only one AudioContext can be current in the application at any time, regardless of the number of threads.

member.name: P:OpenTK.Input.KeyboardDevice.KeyRepeat
member.summary: Gets or sets a System.Boolean indicating key repeat status.
member.remarks:
If KeyRepeat is true, multiple KeyDown events will be generated while a key is being held. Otherwise only one KeyDown event will be reported.
The rate of the generated KeyDown events is controlled by the Operating System. Usually, one KeyDown event will be reported, followed by a small (250-1000ms) pause and several more KeyDown events (6-30 events per second).
Set to true to handle text input (where keyboard repeat is desirable), but set to false for game input.

member.name: M:OpenTK.Graphics.DisplayDevice.SelectResolution(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Single)
member.summary: Selects an available resolution that matches the specified parameters.
member.param: The width of the requested resolution in pixels.
The height of the requested resolution in pixels.
The bits per pixel of the requested resolution.
The refresh rate of the requested resolution in Herz.
member.returns: The requested DisplayResolution or null if the parameters cannot be met.

remarks.para: If a matching resolution is not found, this function will retry ignoring the specified refresh rate, bits per pixel and resolution, in this order. If a matching resolution still doesn't exist, this function will return the current resolution.
A parameter set to 0 or negative numbers will not be used in the search (e.g. if refreshRate is 0, any refresh rate will be considered valid).
This function allocates memory.

member.name: T:OpenTK.Platform.Windows.API
member.summary: For internal use by OpenTK only! Exposes useful native WINAPI methods and structures.

member.name: M:OpenTK.Platform.Windows.Functions.AdjustWindowRect(OpenTK.Platform.Windows.Rectangle@,OpenTK.Platform.Windows.WindowStyle,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Calculates the required size of the window rectangle, based on the desired client-rectangle size. The window rectangle can then be passed to the CreateWindow function to create a window whose client area is the desired size.
member.param: [in, out] Pointer to a RECT structure that contains the coordinates of the top-left and bottom-right corners of the desired client area. When the function returns, the structure contains the coordinates of the top-left and bottom-right corners of the window to accommodate the desired client area.
[in] Specifies the window style of the window whose required size is to be calculated. Note that you cannot specify the WS_OVERLAPPED style.
[in] Specifies whether the window has a menu.
member.returns: If the function succeeds, the return value is nonzero. If the function fails, the return value is zero. To get extended error information, call GetLastError.
member.remarks: A client rectangle is the smallest rectangle that completely encloses a client area. A window rectangle is the smallest rectangle that completely encloses the window, which includes the client area and the nonclient area. The AdjustWindowRect function does not add extra space when a menu bar wraps to two or more rows. The AdjustWindowRect function does not take the WS_VSCROLL or WS_HSCROLL styles into account. To account for the scroll bars, call the GetSystemMetrics function with SM_CXVSCROLL or SM_CYHSCROLL. Found Winuser.h, user32.dll

member.name: M:OpenTK.Platform.Windows.Functions.PeekMessage(OpenTK.Platform.Windows.MSG@,System.IntPtr,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Low-level WINAPI function that checks the next message in the queue.
member.param: The pending message (if any) is stored here.
Not used
Not used
Not used
Not used
member.returns: True if there is a message pending.

member.name: M:OpenTK.Platform.Windows.Functions.GetMessage(OpenTK.Platform.Windows.MSG@,System.IntPtr,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Low-level WINAPI function that retriives the next message in the queue.
member.param: The pending message (if any) is stored here.
Not used
Not used
Not used
member.returns: Nonzero indicates that the function retrieves a message other than WM_QUIT. Zero indicates that the function retrieves the WM_QUIT message, or that lpMsg is an invalid pointer. 1 indicates that an error occurred for example, the function fails if hWnd is an invalid window handle. To get extended error information, call GetLastError.

member.name: M:OpenTK.Platform.Windows.Functions.GetQueueStatus(OpenTK.Platform.Windows.QueueStatusFlags)
member.summary: Indicates the type of messages found in the calling thread's message queue.
member.returns: The high-order word of the return value indicates the types of messages currently in the queue. The low-order word indicates the types of messages that have been added to the queue and that are still in the queue since the last call to the GetQueueStatus, GetMessage, or PeekMessage function.
member.remarks:
The presence of a QS_ flag in the return value does not guarantee that a subsequent call to the GetMessage or PeekMessage function will return a message. GetMessage and PeekMessage perform some internal filtering that may cause the message to be processed internally. For this reason, the return value from GetQueueStatus should be considered only a hint as to whether GetMessage or PeekMessage should be called.
The QS_ALLPOSTMESSAGE and QS_POSTMESSAGE flags differ in when they are cleared. QS_POSTMESSAGE is cleared when you call GetMessage or PeekMessage, whether or not you are filtering messages. QS_ALLPOSTMESSAGE is cleared when you call GetMessage or PeekMessage without filtering messages (wMsgFilterMin and wMsgFilterMax are 0). This can be useful when you call PeekMessage multiple times to get messages in different ranges.

member.name: M:OpenTK.Platform.Windows.Functions.TimeBeginPeriod(System.Int32)
member.summary: Sets the timing resolution of the GetTime (?) method.
member.param: Timing resolution in msec (?)

member.name: M:OpenTK.Platform.Windows.Functions.ShowWindow(System.IntPtr,OpenTK.Platform.Windows.ShowWindowCommand)
member.summary: The ShowWindow function sets the specified window's show state.
member.param: [in] Handle to the window.

[in] Specifies how the window is to be shown. This parameter is ignored the first time an application calls ShowWindow, if the program that launched the application provides a STARTUPINFO structure. Otherwise, the first time ShowWindow is called, the value should be the value obtained by the WinMain function in its nCmdShow parameter. In subsequent calls, this parameter can be one of the ShowWindowEnum values.
member.returns: If the window was previously visible, the return value is true. Otherwise false.

remarks.para: To perform certain special effects when showing or hiding a window, use AnimateWindow.

The first time an application calls ShowWindow, it should use the WinMain function's nCmdShow parameter as its nCmdShow parameter. Subsequent calls to ShowWindow must use one of the values in the given list, instead of the one specified by the WinMain function's nCmdShow parameter.

As noted in the discussion of the nCmdShow parameter, the nCmdShow value is ignored in the first call to ShowWindow if the program that launched the application specifies startup information in the structure. In this case, ShowWindow uses the information specified in the STARTUPINFO structure to show the window. On subsequent calls, the application must call ShowWindow with nCmdShow set to SW_SHOWDEFAULT to use the startup information provided by the program that launched the application. This behavior is designed for the following situations:

list.item: Applications create their main window by calling CreateWindow with the WS_VISIBLE flag set.
Applications create their main window by calling CreateWindow with the WS_VISIBLE flag cleared, and later call ShowWindow with the SW_SHOW flag set to make it visible.

member.name: M:OpenTK.Platform.Windows.Functions.SetWindowText(System.IntPtr,System.String)
member.summary: The SetWindowText function changes the text of the specified window's title bar (if it has one). If the specified window is a control, the text of the control is changed. However, SetWindowText cannot change the text of a control in another application.
member.param: [in] Handle to the window or control whose text is to be changed.
[in] Pointer to a null-terminated string to be used as the new title or control text.

returns.para: If the function succeeds, the return value is nonzero.
If the function fails, the return value is zero. To get extended error information, call GetLastError.

remarks.para: If the target window is owned by the current process, SetWindowText causes a WM_SETTEXT message to be sent to the specified window or control. If the control is a list box control created with the WS_CAPTION style, however, SetWindowText sets the text for the control, not for the list box entries.
To set the text of a control in another process, send the WM_SETTEXT message directly instead of calling SetWindowText.
The SetWindowText function does not expand tab characters (ASCII code 0x09). Tab characters are displayed as vertical bar (|) characters.

Windows 95/98/Me: SetWindowTextW is supported by the Microsoft Layer for Unicode (MSLU). To use this, you must add certain files to your application, as outlined in Microsoft Layer for Unicode on Windows 95/98/Me Systems .

member.name: M:OpenTK.Platform.Windows.Functions.GetWindowText(System.IntPtr,System.Text.StringBuilder,System.Int32)
member.summary: The GetWindowText function copies the text of the specified window's title bar (if it has one) into a buffer. If the specified window is a control, the text of the control is copied. However, GetWindowText cannot retrieve the text of a control in another application.
member.param: [in] Handle to the window or control containing the text.
[out] Pointer to the buffer that will receive the text. If the string is as long or longer than the buffer, the string is truncated and terminated with a NULL character.
[in] Specifies the maximum number of characters to copy to the buffer, including the NULL character. If the text exceeds this limit, it is truncated.
member.returns:
If the function succeeds, the return value is the length, in characters, of the copied string, not including the terminating NULL character. If the window has no title bar or text, if the title bar is empty, or if the window or control handle is invalid, the return value is zero. To get extended error information, call GetLastError.
This function cannot retrieve the text of an edit control in another application.

remarks.para: If the target window is owned by the current process, GetWindowText causes a WM_GETTEXT message to be sent to the specified window or control. If the target window is owned by another process and has a caption, GetWindowText retrieves the window caption text. If the window does not have a caption, the return value is a null string. This behavior is by design. It allows applications to call GetWindowText without becoming unresponsive if the process that owns the target window is not responding. However, if the target window is not responding and it belongs to the calling application, GetWindowText will cause the calling application to become unresponsive.
To retrieve the text of a control in another process, send a WM_GETTEXT message directly instead of calling GetWindowText.

Windows 95/98/Me: GetWindowTextW is supported by the Microsoft Layer for Unicode (MSLU). To use this, you must add certain files to your application, as outlined in Microsoft Layer for Unicode on Windows 95/98/Me

member.name: M:OpenTK.Platform.Windows.Functions.ScreenToClient(System.IntPtr,System.Drawing.Point@)
member.summary: Converts the screen coordinates of a specified point on the screen to client-area coordinates.
member.param: Handle to the window whose client area will be used for the conversion.
Pointer to a POINT structure that specifies the screen coordinates to be converted.
member.returns: If the function succeeds, the return value is nonzero. If the function fails, the return value is zero. Windows NT/2000/XP: To get extended error information, call GetLastError.

remarks.para: The function uses the window identified by the hWnd parameter and the screen coordinates given in the POINT structure to compute client coordinates. It then replaces the screen coordinates with the client coordinates. The new coordinates are relative to the upper-left corner of the specified window's client area.
The ScreenToClient function assumes the specified point is in screen coordinates.
All coordinates are in device units.

Do not use ScreenToClient when in a mirroring situation, that is, when changing from left-to-right layout to right-to-left layout. Instead, use MapWindowPoints. For more information, see "Window Layout and Mirroring" in Window Features.

member.name: M:OpenTK.Platform.Windows.Functions.ClientToScreen(System.IntPtr,System.Drawing.Point@)
member.summary: Converts the client-area coordinates of a specified point to screen coordinates.
member.param: Handle to the window whose client area will be used for the conversion.
Pointer to a POINT structure that contains the client coordinates to be converted. The new screen coordinates are copied into this structure if the function succeeds.
member.returns: If the function succeeds, the return value is nonzero. If the function fails, the return value is zero. Windows NT/2000/XP: To get extended error information, call GetLastError.

remarks.para: The ClientToScreen function replaces the client-area coordinates in the POINT structure with the screen coordinates. The screen coordinates are relative to the upper-left corner of the screen. Note, a screen-coordinate point that is above the window's client area has a negative y-coordinate. Similarly, a screen coordinate to the left of a client area has a negative x-coordinate.
All coordinates are device coordinates.

member.name: M:OpenTK.Platform.Windows.Functions.GetClientRect(System.IntPtr,OpenTK.Platform.Windows.Rectangle@)
member.summary: The GetClientRect function retrieves the coordinates of a window's client area. The client coordinates specify the upper-left and lower-right corners of the client area. Because client coordinates are relative to the upper-left corner of a window's client area, the coordinates of the upper-left corner are (0,0).
member.param: Handle to the window whose client coordinates are to be retrieved.
Pointer to a RECT structure that receives the client coordinates. The left and top members are zero. The right and bottom members contain the width and height of the window.

returns.para: If the function succeeds, the return value is nonzero.
If the function fails, the return value is zero. To get extended error information, call GetLastError.

member.remarks: In conformance with conventions for the RECT structure, the bottom-right coordinates of the returned rectangle are exclusive. In other words, the pixel at (right, bottom) lies immediately outside the rectangle.

member.name: M:OpenTK.Platform.Windows.Functions.ChangeDisplaySettings(OpenTK.Platform.Windows.DeviceMode,OpenTK.Platform.Windows.ChangeDisplaySettingsEnum)
member.summary: The ChangeDisplaySettings function changes the settings of the default display device to the specified graphics mode.
member.param: [in] Pointer to a DEVMODE structure that describes the new graphics mode. If lpDevMode is NULL, all the values currently in the registry will be used for the display setting. Passing NULL for the lpDevMode parameter and 0 for the dwFlags parameter is the easiest way to return to the default mode after a dynamic mode change.
[in] Indicates how the graphics mode should be changed.
member.remarks:
To change the settings of a specified display device, use the ChangeDisplaySettingsEx function.
To ensure that the DEVMODE structure passed to ChangeDisplaySettings is valid and contains only values supported by the display driver, use the DEVMODE returned by the EnumDisplaySettings function.
When the display mode is changed dynamically, the WM_DISPLAYCHANGE message is sent to all running applications.

member.name: M:OpenTK.Platform.Windows.Functions.GetCursorPos(System.Drawing.Point@)
member.summary: Retrieves the cursor's position, in screen coordinates.
member.param: Pointer to a POINT structure that receives the screen coordinates of the cursor.
member.returns: Returns nonzero if successful or zero otherwise. To get extended error information, call GetLastError.

remarks.para: The cursor position is always specified in screen coordinates and is not affected by the mapping mode of the window that contains the cursor.
The calling process must have WINSTA_READATTRIBUTES access to the window station.

The input desktop must be the current desktop when you call GetCursorPos. Call OpenInputDesktop to determine whether the current desktop is the input desktop. If it is not, call SetThreadDesktop with the HDESK returned by OpenInputDesktop to switch to that desktop.

member.name: M:OpenTK.Platform.Windows.Functions.GetRawInputBuffer(OpenTK.Platform.Windows.RawInput[],System.UInt32@,System.UInt32)
member.summary: Does a buffered read of the raw input data.
member.param: Pointer to a buffer of RawInput structures that contain the raw input data. If NULL, the minimum required buffer, in bytes, is returned in Size.
Pointer to a variable that specifies the size, in bytes, of a RawInput structure.
Size, in bytes, of RawInputHeader.
member.returns: If Data is NULL and the function is successful, the return value is zero. If Data is not NULL and the function is successful, the return value is the number of RawInput structures written to Data. If an error occurs, the return value is (UINT)-1. Call GetLastError for the error code.

member.name: M:OpenTK.Platform.Windows.Functions.GetRegisteredRawInputDevices(OpenTK.Platform.Windows.RawInput[],System.UInt32@,System.UInt32)
member.summary: Gets the information about the raw input devices for the current application.
member.param: Pointer to an array of RawInputDevice structures for the application.
Number of RawInputDevice structures in RawInputDevices.
Size, in bytes, of a RawInputDevice structure.

returns.para: If successful, the function returns a non-negative number that is the number of RawInputDevice structures written to the buffer.
If the pRawInputDevices buffer is too small or NULL, the function sets the last error as ERROR_INSUFFICIENT_BUFFER, returns -1, and sets NumDevices to the required number of devices.
If the function fails for any other reason, it returns -1. For more details, call GetLastError.

member.name: M:OpenTK.Platform.Windows.Functions.GetRawInputDeviceList(OpenTK.Platform.Windows.RawInputDeviceList[],System.UInt32@,System.UInt32)
member.summary: Enumerates the raw input devices attached to the system.
member.param: ointer to buffer that holds an array of RawInputDeviceList structures for the devices attached to the system. If NULL, the number of devices are returned in NumDevices.

Pointer to a variable. If RawInputDeviceList is NULL, it specifies the number of devices attached to the system. Otherwise, it contains the size, in bytes, of the preallocated buffer pointed to by pRawInputDeviceList. However, if NumDevices is smaller than needed to contain RawInputDeviceList structures, the required buffer size is returned here.
Size of a RawInputDeviceList structure.
member.returns: If the function is successful, the return value is the number of devices stored in the buffer pointed to by RawInputDeviceList. If RawInputDeviceList is NULL, the return value is zero. If NumDevices is smaller than needed to contain all the RawInputDeviceList structures, the return value is (UINT) -1 and the required buffer is returned in NumDevices. Calling GetLastError returns ERROR_INSUFFICIENT_BUFFER. On any other error, the function returns (UINT) -1 and GetLastError returns the error indication.

member.name: M:OpenTK.Platform.Windows.Functions.GetRawInputDeviceList(System.IntPtr,System.UInt32@,System.UInt32)

member.name: M:OpenTK.Platform.Windows.Functions.GetRawInputDeviceInfo(System.IntPtr,OpenTK.Platform.Windows.RawInputDeviceInfoEnum,System.IntPtr,System.UInt32@)
member.summary: Gets information about the raw input device.
member.param: Handle to the raw input device. This comes from the lParam of the WM_INPUT message, from RawInputHeader.Device, or from GetRawInputDeviceList. It can also be NULL if an application inserts input data, for example, by using SendInput.

Specifies what data will be returned in pData. It can be one of the following values. RawInputDeviceInfoEnum.PREPARSEDDATA Data points to the previously parsed data. RawInputDeviceInfoEnum.DEVICENAME Data points to a string that contains the device name. For this Command only, the value in Size is the character count (not the byte count). RawInputDeviceInfoEnum.DEVICEINFO Data points to an RawInputDeviceInfo structure.

ointer to a buffer that contains the information specified by Command. If Command is RawInputDeviceInfoEnum.DEVICEINFO, set RawInputDeviceInfo.Size to sizeof(RawInputDeviceInfo) before calling GetRawInputDeviceInfo. (This is done automatically in OpenTK)
Pointer to a variable that contains the size, in bytes, of the data in Data.

returns.para: If successful, this function returns a non-negative number indicating the number of bytes copied to Data.

If Data is not large enough for the data, the function returns -1. If Data is NULL, the function returns a value of zero. In both of these cases, Size is set to the minimum size required for the Data buffer.
Call GetLastError to identify any other errors.

ointer to a buffer that contains the information specified by Command. If Command is RawInputDeviceInfoEnum.DEVICEINFO, set RawInputDeviceInfo.Size to sizeof(RawInputDeviceInfo) before calling GetRawInputDeviceInfo. (This is done automatically in OpenTK)
Pointer to a variable that contains the size, in bytes, of the data in Data.

returns.para: If successful, this function returns a non-negative number indicating the number of bytes copied to Data.

member.name: M:OpenTK.Platform.Windows.Functions.GetRawInputData(System.IntPtr,OpenTK.Platform.Windows.GetRawInputDataEnum,System.IntPtr,System.UInt32@,System.UInt32)
member.summary: Gets the raw input from the specified device.
member.param: Handle to the RawInput structure. This comes from the lParam in WM_INPUT.

Command flag. This parameter can be one of the following values. RawInputDateEnum.INPUT Get the raw data from the RawInput structure. RawInputDateEnum.HEADER Get the header information from the RawInput structure.
Pointer to the data that comes from the RawInput structure. This depends on the value of uiCommand. If Data is NULL, the required size of the buffer is returned in Size.
Pointer to a variable that specifies the size, in bytes, of the data in Data.
Size, in bytes, of RawInputHeader.

returns.para: If Data is NULL and the function is successful, the return value is 0. If Data is not NULL and the function is successful, the return value is the number of bytes copied into Data.
If there is an error, the return value is (UINT)-1.

member.remarks: GetRawInputData gets the raw input one RawInput structure at a time. In contrast, GetRawInputBuffer gets an array of RawInput structures.

member.name: M:OpenTK.Platform.Windows.Functions.GetRawInputData(System.IntPtr,OpenTK.Platform.Windows.GetRawInputDataEnum,OpenTK.Platform.Windows.RawInput@,System.UInt32@,System.UInt32)
member.summary: Gets the raw input from the specified device.
member.param: Handle to the RawInput structure. This comes from the lParam in WM_INPUT.

Command flag. This parameter can be one of the following values. RawInputDateEnum.INPUT Get the raw data from the RawInput structure. RawInputDateEnum.HEADER Get the header information from the RawInput structure.
Pointer to the data that comes from the RawInput structure. This depends on the value of uiCommand. If Data is NULL, the required size of the buffer is returned in Size.
Pointer to a variable that specifies the size, in bytes, of the data in Data.
Size, in bytes, of RawInputHeader.

returns.para: If Data is NULL and the function is successful, the return value is 0. If Data is not NULL and the function is successful, the return value is the number of bytes copied into Data.
If there is an error, the return value is (UINT)-1.

member.remarks: GetRawInputData gets the raw input one RawInput structure at a time. In contrast, GetRawInputBuffer gets an array of RawInput structures.

member.name: F:OpenTK.Platform.Windows.CreateStruct.lpCreateParams
member.summary: Contains additional data which may be used to create the window.
member.remarks:
If the window is being created as a result of a call to the CreateWindow or CreateWindowEx function, this member contains the value of the lpParam parameter specified in the function call.
If the window being created is a multiple-document interface (MDI) client window, this member contains a pointer to a CLIENTCREATESTRUCT structure. If the window being created is a MDI child window, this member contains a pointer to an MDICREATESTRUCT structure.
Windows NT/2000/XP: If the window is being created from a dialog template, this member is the address of a SHORT value that specifies the size, in bytes, of the window creation data. The value is immediately followed by the creation data.
Windows NT/2000/XP: You should access the data represented by the lpCreateParams member using a pointer that has been declared using the UNALIGNED type, because the pointer may not be DWORD aligned.

member.name: F:OpenTK.Platform.Windows.CreateStruct.hInstance
member.summary: Handle to the module that owns the new window.

member.name: F:OpenTK.Platform.Windows.CreateStruct.hMenu
member.summary: Handle to the menu to be used by the new window.

member.name: F:OpenTK.Platform.Windows.CreateStruct.hwndParent
member.summary: Handle to the parent window, if the window is a child window. If the window is owned, this member identifies the owner window. If the window is not a child or owned window, this member is NULL.

member.summary: Specifies the y-coordinate of the upper left corner of the new window. If the new window is a child window, coordinates are relative to the parent window. Otherwise, the coordinates are relative to the screen origin.

member.name: F:OpenTK.Platform.Windows.CreateStruct.x
member.summary: Specifies the x-coordinate of the upper left corner of the new window. If the new window is a child window, coordinates are relative to the parent window. Otherwise, the coordinates are relative to the screen origin.

member.summary: Specifies the style for the new window.

member.name: F:OpenTK.Platform.Windows.CreateStruct.lpszName
member.summary: Pointer to a null-terminated string that specifies the name of the new window.

member.name: F:OpenTK.Platform.Windows.CreateStruct.lpszClass
member.summary:
Either a pointer to a null-terminated string or an atom that specifies the class name of the new window.
Note Because the lpszClass member can contain a pointer to a local (and thus inaccessable) atom, do not obtain the class name by using this member. Use the GetClassName function instead.

member.name: F:OpenTK.Platform.Windows.CreateStruct.dwExStyle

member.summary: Specifies the position of the window in Z order (front-to-back position). This member can be a handle to the window behind which this window is placed, or can be one of the special values listed with the SetWindowPos function.

member.summary: Specifies the position of the left edge of the window.

member.summary: Specifies the window position.

member.name: F:OpenTK.Platform.Windows.SetWindowPosFlags.NOSIZE
member.summary: Retains the current size (ignores the cx and cy parameters).

member.name: F:OpenTK.Platform.Windows.SetWindowPosFlags.NOMOVE
member.summary: Retains the current position (ignores the x and y parameters).

member.name: F:OpenTK.Platform.Windows.SetWindowPosFlags.NOZORDER
member.summary: Retains the current Z order (ignores the hwndInsertAfter parameter).

member.name: F:OpenTK.Platform.Windows.SetWindowPosFlags.NOREDRAW
member.summary: Does not redraw changes. If this flag is set, no repainting of any kind occurs. This applies to the client area, the nonclient area (including the title bar and scroll bars), and any part of the parent window uncovered as a result of the window being moved. When this flag is set, the application must explicitly invalidate or redraw any parts of the window and parent window that need redrawing.

member.name: F:OpenTK.Platform.Windows.SetWindowPosFlags.NOACTIVATE
member.summary: Does not activate the window. If this flag is not set, the window is activated and moved to the top of either the topmost or non-topmost group (depending on the setting of the hwndInsertAfter member).

member.name: F:OpenTK.Platform.Windows.SetWindowPosFlags.FRAMECHANGED
member.summary: Sends a WM_NCCALCSIZE message to the window, even if the window's size is not being changed. If this flag is not specified, WM_NCCALCSIZE is sent only when the window's size is being changed.

member.name: F:OpenTK.Platform.Windows.SetWindowPosFlags.SHOWWINDOW
member.summary: Displays the window.

member.name: F:OpenTK.Platform.Windows.SetWindowPosFlags.HIDEWINDOW
member.summary: Hides the window.

member.name: F:OpenTK.Platform.Windows.SetWindowPosFlags.NOCOPYBITS
member.summary: Discards the entire contents of the client area. If this flag is not specified, the valid contents of the client area are saved and copied back into the client area after the window is sized or repositioned.

member.name: F:OpenTK.Platform.Windows.SetWindowPosFlags.NOOWNERZORDER
member.summary: Does not change the owner window's position in the Z order.

member.name: F:OpenTK.Platform.Windows.SetWindowPosFlags.NOSENDCHANGING
member.summary: Prevents the window from receiving the WM_WINDOWPOSCHANGING message.

member.name: F:OpenTK.Platform.Windows.SetWindowPosFlags.DRAWFRAME
member.summary: Draws a frame (defined in the window's class description) around the window.

member.name: F:OpenTK.Platform.Windows.SetWindowPosFlags.NOREPOSITION
member.summary: Same as the NOOWNERZORDER flag.

member.name: T:OpenTK.Platform.Windows.RawInputDevice
member.summary: Defines information for the raw input devices.
member.remarks: If RIDEV_NOLEGACY is set for a mouse or a keyboard, the system does not generate any legacy message for that device for the application. For example, if the mouse TLC is set with RIDEV_NOLEGACY, WM_LBUTTONDOWN and related legacy mouse messages are not generated. Likewise, if the keyboard TLC is set with RIDEV_NOLEGACY, WM_KEYDOWN and related legacy keyboard messages are not generated.

member.name: F:OpenTK.Platform.Windows.RawInputDevice.UsagePage
member.summary: Top level collection Usage page for the raw input device.

member.name: F:OpenTK.Platform.Windows.RawInputDevice.Usage
member.summary: Top level collection Usage for the raw input device.

member.name: F:OpenTK.Platform.Windows.RawInputDevice.Flags
member.summary: Mode flag that specifies how to interpret the information provided by UsagePage and Usage. It can be zero (the default) or one of the following values. By default, the operating system sends raw input from devices with the specified top level collection (TLC) to the registered application as long as it has the window focus.

member.name: F:OpenTK.Platform.Windows.RawInputDevice.Target
member.summary: Handle to the target window. If NULL it follows the keyboard focus.

member.name: F:OpenTK.Platform.Windows.RawInputDeviceList.Type
member.summary: Type of device.

member.name: T:OpenTK.Platform.Windows.RawInput
member.summary: Contains the raw input from a device.

remarks.para: The handle to this structure is passed in the lParam parameter of WM_INPUT.
To get detailed information -- such as the header and the content of the raw input -- call GetRawInputData.
To get device specific information, call GetRawInputDeviceInfo with the hDevice from RAWINPUTHEADER.
Raw input is available only when the application calls RegisterRawInputDevices with valid device specifications.

member.name: T:OpenTK.Platform.Windows.RawInputHeader
member.summary: Contains the header information that is part of the raw input data.
member.remarks: To get more information on the device, use hDevice in a call to GetRawInputDeviceInfo.

member.summary: Type of raw input.

member.name: F:OpenTK.Platform.Windows.RawInputHeader.Size
member.summary: Size, in bytes, of the entire input packet of data. This includes the RawInput struct plus possible extra input reports in the RAWHID variable length array.

member.name: F:OpenTK.Platform.Windows.RawInputHeader.Device
member.summary: Handle to the device generating the raw input data.

member.name: F:OpenTK.Platform.Windows.RawInputHeader.Param
member.summary: Value passed in the wParam parameter of the WM_INPUT message.

MOUSE_VIRTUAL_DESKTOP Mouse coordinates are mapped to the virtual desktop (for a multiple monitor system).

member.name: T:OpenTK.Platform.Windows.Rectangle
member.summary: Defines the coordinates of the upper-left and lower-right corners of a rectangle.
member.remarks: By convention, the right and bottom edges of the rectangle are normally considered exclusive. In other words, the pixel whose coordinates are (right, bottom) lies immediately outside of the the rectangle. For example, when RECT is passed to the FillRect function, the rectangle is filled up to, but not including, the right column and bottom row of pixels. This structure is identical to the RECTL structure.

member.summary: Specifies the x-coordinate of the upper-left corner of the rectangle.

member.summary: Specifies the y-coordinate of the upper-left corner of the rectangle.

member.name: F:OpenTK.Platform.Windows.Rectangle.right
member.summary: Specifies the x-coordinate of the lower-right corner of the rectangle.

member.name: F:OpenTK.Platform.Windows.Rectangle.bottom
member.summary: Specifies the y-coordinate of the lower-right corner of the rectangle.

member.summary: The width of the window border, in pixels.

member.name: F:OpenTK.Platform.Windows.WindowInfo.CreatorVersion
member.summary: The Microsoft Windows version of the application that created the window.

member.name: F:OpenTK.Platform.Windows.RawInputDeviceFlags.REMOVE
member.summary: If set, this removes the top level collection from the inclusion list. This tells the operating system to stop reading from a device which matches the top level collection.

member.name: F:OpenTK.Platform.Windows.RawInputDeviceFlags.EXCLUDE
member.summary: If set, this specifies the top level collections to exclude when reading a complete usage page. This flag only affects a TLC whose usage page is already specified with RawInputDeviceEnum.PAGEONLY.

member.name: F:OpenTK.Platform.Windows.RawInputDeviceFlags.PAGEONLY
member.summary: If set, this specifies all devices whose top level collection is from the specified UsagePage. Note that usUsage must be zero. To exclude a particular top level collection, use EXCLUDE.

member.name: F:OpenTK.Platform.Windows.RawInputDeviceFlags.NOLEGACY
member.summary: If set, this prevents any devices specified by UsagePage or Usage from generating legacy messages. This is only for the mouse and keyboard. See RawInputDevice Remarks.

member.name: F:OpenTK.Platform.Windows.RawInputDeviceFlags.INPUTSINK
member.summary: If set, this enables the caller to receive the input even when the caller is not in the foreground. Note that Target must be specified in RawInputDevice.

member.name: F:OpenTK.Platform.Windows.RawInputDeviceFlags.CAPTUREMOUSE
member.summary: If set, the mouse button click does not activate the other window.

member.name: F:OpenTK.Platform.Windows.RawInputDeviceFlags.NOHOTKEYS
member.summary: If set, the application-defined keyboard device hotkeys are not handled. However, the system hotkeys; for example, ALT+TAB and CTRL+ALT+DEL, are still handled. By default, all keyboard hotkeys are handled. NOHOTKEYS can be specified even if NOLEGACY is not specified and Target is NULL in RawInputDevice.

member.name: F:OpenTK.Platform.Windows.RawInputDeviceFlags.APPKEYS
member.summary: Microsoft Windows XP Service Pack 1 (SP1): If set, the application command keys are handled. APPKEYS can be specified only if NOLEGACY is specified for a keyboard device.

member.name: F:OpenTK.Platform.Windows.RawInputDeviceFlags.EXINPUTSINK
member.summary: If set, this enables the caller to receive input in the background only if the foreground application does not process it. In other words, if the foreground application is not registered for raw input, then the background application that is registered will receive the input.

member.name: T:OpenTK.Platform.Windows.RawMouseFlags
member.summary: Mouse indicator flags (found in winuser.h).

member.name: F:OpenTK.Platform.Windows.RawMouseFlags.MOUSE_MOVE_RELATIVE
member.summary: LastX/Y indicate relative motion.

member.name: F:OpenTK.Platform.Windows.RawMouseFlags.MOUSE_MOVE_ABSOLUTE
member.summary: LastX/Y indicate absolute motion.

member.name: F:OpenTK.Platform.Windows.RawMouseFlags.MOUSE_VIRTUAL_DESKTOP
member.summary: The coordinates are mapped to the virtual desktop.

member.name: F:OpenTK.Platform.Windows.RawMouseFlags.MOUSE_ATTRIBUTES_CHANGED
member.summary: Requery for mouse attributes.

member.name: T:OpenTK.Platform.Windows.MouseKeys
member.summary: Enumerates available mouse keys (suitable for use in WM_MOUSEMOVE messages).

member.name: F:OpenTK.Platform.Windows.QueueStatusFlags.ALLPOSTMESSAGE

member.summary: A raw input message is in the queue. For more information, see Raw Input. Windows XP and higher only.

member.name: F:OpenTK.Platform.Windows.QueueStatusFlags.MOUSE
member.summary: A WM_MOUSEMOVE message or mouse-button message (WM_LBUTTONUP, WM_RBUTTONDOWN, and so on).

member.name: F:OpenTK.Platform.Windows.QueueStatusFlags.INPUT

member.name: F:OpenTK.Platform.Windows.QueueStatusFlags.INPUT_LEGACY

member.name: F:OpenTK.Platform.Windows.QueueStatusFlags.ALLEVENTS
member.summary: An input, WM_TIMER, WM_PAINT, WM_HOTKEY, or posted message is in the queue.

member.name: F:OpenTK.Platform.Windows.QueueStatusFlags.ALLINPUT

member.name: T:OpenTK.Platform.Windows.ShowWindowCommand
member.summary: ShowWindow() Commands

member.name: F:OpenTK.Platform.Windows.ShowWindowCommand.HIDE
member.summary: Hides the window and activates another window.

member.name: F:OpenTK.Platform.Windows.ShowWindowCommand.SHOWNORMAL
member.summary: Activates and displays a window. If the window is minimized or maximized, the system restores it to its original size and position. An application should specify this flag when displaying the window for the first time.

member.name: F:OpenTK.Platform.Windows.ShowWindowCommand.SHOWMINIMIZED
member.summary: Activates the window and displays it as a minimized window.

member.name: F:OpenTK.Platform.Windows.ShowWindowCommand.SHOWMAXIMIZED
member.summary: Activates the window and displays it as a maximized window.

member.name: F:OpenTK.Platform.Windows.ShowWindowCommand.SHOWNOACTIVATE
member.summary: Displays the window as a minimized window. This value is similar to SW_SHOWMINIMIZED, except the window is not activated.

member.name: F:OpenTK.Platform.Windows.ShowWindowCommand.SHOW
member.summary: Activates the window and displays it in its current size and position.

member.name: F:OpenTK.Platform.Windows.ShowWindowCommand.MINIMIZE
member.summary: Minimizes the specified window and activates the next top-level window in the Z order.

member.name: F:OpenTK.Platform.Windows.ShowWindowCommand.SHOWMINNOACTIVE
member.summary: Displays the window as a minimized window. This value is similar to SW_SHOWMINIMIZED, except the window is not activated.

member.name: F:OpenTK.Platform.Windows.ShowWindowCommand.SHOWNA
member.summary: Displays the window in its current size and position. This value is similar to SW_SHOW, except the window is not activated.

member.name: F:OpenTK.Platform.Windows.ShowWindowCommand.RESTORE
member.summary: Activates and displays the window. If the window is minimized or maximized, the system restores it to its original size and position. An application should specify this flag when restoring a minimized window.

member.name: F:OpenTK.Platform.Windows.ShowWindowCommand.SHOWDEFAULT
member.summary: Sets the show state based on the SW_ value specified in the STARTUPINFO structure passed to the CreateProcess function by the program that started the application.

member.name: F:OpenTK.Platform.Windows.ShowWindowCommand.FORCEMINIMIZE
member.summary: Windows 2000/XP: Minimizes a window, even if the thread that owns the window is not responding. This flag should only be used when minimizing windows from a different thread.

member.name: T:OpenTK.Platform.Windows.ShowWindowMessageIdentifiers
member.summary: Identifiers for the WM_SHOWWINDOW message

member.name: T:OpenTK.Platform.Windows.GdiCharset
member.summary: Enumerates the available character sets.

member.name: F:OpenTK.Platform.Windows.MapVirtualKeyType.VirtualKeyToScanCode
member.summary: uCode is a virtual-key code and is translated into a scan code. If it is a virtual-key code that does not distinguish between left- and right-hand keys, the left-hand scan code is returned. If there is no translation, the function returns 0.

member.name: F:OpenTK.Platform.Windows.MapVirtualKeyType.ScanCodeToVirtualKey
member.summary: uCode is a scan code and is translated into a virtual-key code that does not distinguish between left- and right-hand keys. If there is no translation, the function returns 0.

member.name: F:OpenTK.Platform.Windows.MapVirtualKeyType.VirtualKeyToCharacter
member.summary: uCode is a virtual-key code and is translated into an unshifted character value in the low-order word of the return value. Dead keys (diacritics) are indicated by setting the top bit of the return value. If there is no translation, the function returns 0.

member.name: F:OpenTK.Platform.Windows.MapVirtualKeyType.ScanCodeToVirtualKeyExtended
member.summary: Windows NT/2000/XP: uCode is a scan code and is translated into a virtual-key code that distinguishes between left- and right-hand keys. If there is no translation, the function returns 0.

member.name: T:OpenTK.Platform.Utilities
member.summary: Provides cross-platform utilities to help interact with the underlying platform.

member.name: M:OpenTK.Platform.Utilities.LoadExtensions(System.Type)
member.summary: Loads all extensions for the specified class. This function is intended for OpenGL, Wgl, Glx, OpenAL etc.
member.param: The class to load extensions for.

remarks.para: The Type must contain a nested class called "Delegates".
The Type must also implement a static function called LoadDelegate with the following signature: static Delegate LoadDelegate(string name, Type signature)
This function allocates memory.

member.name: M:OpenTK.Platform.Utilities.TryLoadExtension(System.Type,System.String)
member.summary: Loads the specified extension for the specified class. This function is intended for OpenGL, Wgl, Glx, OpenAL etc.
member.param: The class to load extensions for.
The extension to load.

remarks.para: The Type must contain a nested class called "Delegates".
The Type must also implement a static function called LoadDelegate with the following signature: static Delegate LoadDelegate(string name, Type signature)
This function allocates memory.

member.name: M:OpenTK.Math.Functions.InverseSqrtFast(System.Single)
member.summary: Returns an approximation of the inverse square root of left number.
member.param: A number.
member.returns: An approximation of the inverse square root of the specified number, with an upper error bound of 0.001
member.remarks: This is an improved implementation of the the method known as Carmack's inverse square root which is found in the Quake III source code. This implementation comes from http://www.codemaestro.com/reviews/review00000105.html. For the history of this method, see http://www.beyond3d.com/content/articles/8/

member.name: M:OpenTK.Audio.AL.GetError
member.summary: Error support. Obtain the most recent error generated in the AL state machine. When an error is detected by AL, a flag is set and the error code is recorded. Further errors, if they occur, do not affect this recorded code. When alGetError is called, the code is returned and the flag is cleared, so that a further error will again record its code.
member.returns: The first error that occured. can be used with AL.GetString. Returns an Alenum representing the error state. When an OpenAL error occurs, the error state is set and will not be changed until the error state is retrieved using alGetError. Whenever alGetError is called, the error state is cleared and the last state (the current state when the call was made) is returned. To isolate error detection to a specific portion of code, alGetError should be called before the isolated section to clear the current error state.

member.name: M:OpenTK.Audio.AL.IsExtensionPresent(System.String)
member.summary: This function tests if a specific Extension is available for the OpenAL driver.
member.param: A string naming the desired extension. Example: "EAX-RAM"
member.returns: Returns True if the Extension is available or False if not available.

member.name: M:OpenTK.Audio.AL.GetProcAddress(System.String)
member.summary: This function returns the address of an OpenAL extension function. Handle with care.
member.param: A string containing the function name.
member.returns: The return value is a pointer to the specified function. The return value will be IntPtr.Zero if the function is not found.

member.name: M:OpenTK.Audio.AL.GetEnumValue(System.String)
member.summary: This function returns the enumeration value of an OpenAL token, described by a string.
member.param: A string describing an OpenAL token. Example "AL_DISTANCE_MODEL"
member.returns: Returns the actual ALenum described by a string. Returns 0 if the string doesnt describe a valid OpenAL token.

member.name: M:OpenTK.Audio.AL.SourcePlay(System.Int32,System.UInt32*)
member.summary: This function plays a set of sources. The playing sources will have their state changed to ALSourceState.Playing. When called on a source which is already playing, the source will restart at the beginning. When the attached buffer(s) are done playing, the source will progress to the ALSourceState.Stopped state.
member.param: The number of sources to be played.
A pointer to an array of sources to be played.

member.name: M:OpenTK.Audio.AL.SourceQueueBuffers(System.UInt32,System.Int32,System.UInt32*)
member.summary: This function queues a set of buffers on a source. All buffers attached to a source will be played in sequence, and the number of processed buffers can be detected using AL.GetSource with parameter ALGetSourcei.BuffersProcessed. When first created, a source will be of type ALSourceType.Undetermined. A successful AL.SourceQueueBuffers call will change the source type to ALSourceType.Streaming.
member.param: The name of the source to queue buffers onto.
The number of buffers to be queued.
A pointer to an array of buffer names to be queued.

member.name: M:OpenTK.Audio.AL.SourceQueueBuffers(System.UInt32,System.Int32,System.UInt32[])
member.summary: This function queues a set of buffers on a source. All buffers attached to a source will be played in sequence, and the number of processed buffers can be detected using AL.GetSource with parameter ALGetSourcei.BuffersProcessed. When first created, a source will be of type ALSourceType.Undetermined. A successful AL.SourceQueueBuffers call will change the source type to ALSourceType.Streaming.
member.param: The name of the source to queue buffers onto.
The number of buffers to be queued.
A pointer to an array of buffer names to be queued.

member.name: M:OpenTK.Audio.AL.SourceUnqueueBuffers(System.UInt32,System.Int32,System.UInt32*)
member.summary: This function unqueues a set of buffers attached to a source. The number of processed buffers can be detected using AL.GetSource with parameter ALGetSourcei.BuffersProcessed, which is the maximum number of buffers that can be unqueued using this call. The unqueue operation will only take place if all n buffers can be removed from the queue.
member.param: The name of the source to unqueue buffers from.
The number of buffers to be unqueued.
A pointer to an array of buffer names that were removed.

member.name: M:OpenTK.Audio.AL.GenBuffers(System.Int32,System.UInt32*)
member.summary: This function generates one or more buffers, which contain audio buffer (see AL.BufferData). References to buffers are uint values, which are used wherever a buffer reference is needed (in calls such as AL.DeleteBuffers, AL.Source with parameter ALSourcei, AL.SourceQueueBuffers, and AL.SourceUnqueueBuffers).
member.param: The number of buffers to be generated.
Pointer to an array of uint values which will store the names of the new buffers.

member.name: M:OpenTK.Audio.AL.DeleteBuffers(System.Int32,System.UInt32*)
member.summary: This function deletes one or more buffers, freeing the resources used by the buffer. Buffers which are attached to a source can not be deleted. See AL.Source (ALSourcei) and AL.SourceUnqueueBuffers for information on how to detach a buffer from a source.
member.param: The number of buffers to be deleted.
Pointer to an array of buffer names identifying the buffers to be deleted.

member.summary: This function fills a buffer with audio buffer. All the pre-defined formats are PCM buffer, but this function may be used by extensions to load other buffer types as well.

Format type from among the following: ALFormat.Mono8, ALFormat.Mono16, ALFormat.Stereo8, ALFormat.Stereo16.

The size of the audio buffer in bytes.
The frequency of the audio buffer.

member.name: M:OpenTK.Audio.AL.DopplerFactor(System.Single)
member.summary: AL.DopplerFactor is a simple scaling of source and listener velocities to exaggerate or deemphasize the Doppler (pitch) shift resulting from the calculation.
member.param: A negative value will result in an error, the command is then ignored. The default value is 1f. The current setting can be queried using AL.Get with parameter ALGetFloat.SpeedOfSound.

member.name: M:OpenTK.Audio.AL.DopplerVelocity(System.Single)
member.summary: This function is deprecated and should not be used.
member.param: The default is 1.0f.

member.name: M:OpenTK.Audio.AL.SpeedOfSound(System.Single)
member.summary: AL.SpeedOfSound allows the application to change the reference (propagation) speed used in the Doppler calculation. The source and listener velocities should be expressed in the same units as the speed of sound.
member.param: A negative or zero value will result in an error, and the command is ignored. Default: 343.3f (appropriate for velocity units of meters and air as the propagation medium). The current setting can be queried using AL.Get with parameter ALGetFloat.SpeedOfSound.

member.name: M:OpenTK.Audio.AL.DistanceModel(OpenTK.Audio.ALDistanceModel)
member.summary: This function selects the OpenAL distance model ALDistanceModel.InverseDistance, ALDistanceModel.InverseDistanceClamped, ALDistanceModel.LinearDistance, ALDistanceModel.LinearDistanceClamped, ALDistanceModel.ExponentDistance, ALDistanceModel.ExponentDistanceClamped, or ALDistanceModel.None. The default distance model in OpenAL is ALDistanceModel.InverseDistanceClamped.

member.name: F:OpenTK.Audio.SampleFormat.Mono8
member.summary: 8 bits per sample, 1 channel.

member.name: F:OpenTK.Audio.SampleFormat.Mono16
member.summary: 16 bits per sample, 1 channel.

member.name: F:OpenTK.Audio.SampleFormat.Stereo8
member.summary: 8 bits per sample, 2 channels.

member.name: F:OpenTK.Audio.SampleFormat.Stereo16
member.summary: 16 bits per sample, 2 channels.
